text: if you've been following along with my
content then you know I have a certain
affinity for split keyboards by using
them it's substantially improve the way
that I type coercing me into using good
touch typing technique whilst preventing
me from unnaturally bending my thumbs
and wrists whilst these keyboards are
great they do have one big problem the
price take for example the CSA
moonlander which is currently my
favorite keyboard however it's not
exactly affordable starting at $365
for most people that's understandably
out of budget especially for a keyboard
but what if you are looking for a more
ergonomic keyboard to improve your hand
Health what options are there well
recently I've been trying out the Kyron
V10 Max which was sent to me for free in
order to do a review after having used
it for about a month I think it's a
fantastic option for those looking for
an affordable split keyboard one that
you can do a lot of customization on in
fact there's one feature about this
keyboard that I really like one that if
Kyron had taken just a little bit
further would make this keyboard
Practically Perfect before I jump into
what I like about this keyboard let me
give a quick disclaimer as I mentioned
before the V10 Max was sent to me for
free by Kyron for the purpose of doing a
review however this video isn't
sponsored and Kyron haven't seen this
video before it's gone live additionally
everything contained in this video is my
own honest opinion however as I always
say always be skeptical of anything
think you see online with that out of
the way let's take a closer look at the
V10 Max the V10 Max is a 75% keyboard
with an ALICE layout this is an
ergonomic layout where the innermost
four columns on each hand have been
split and separated and angled inwards
with the remaining Keys having a slight
symmetric stagger this layout helps to
keep your wrists at a much more natural
position especially compared to when
using a normal keyboard This does mean
that the keyboard itself takes a lot
more space despite it being 7 5% I.E not
having a numpad this isn't exactly
uncommon when it comes to split
keyboards however when it comes to
connectivity the keyboard itself
supports three different modes the first
of which being wired using the provided
USBC cable or the USBC to usba adapter
the second option is Wireless over
Bluetooth with support for three
different hosts these can be toggled by
holding the function key and pressing
either 1 2 or 3 the third and final
option is Wireless over 2.4 4 GHz using
the provided dongle actually two dongles
one for usba a and one for USB C which
is pretty nice both of these dongles are
able to be stored on the keyboard itself
which is a feature I really appreciate
as whenever a keyboard doesn't have this
it's only a matter of time before I
really wish it had having this three
modes of connectivity provides a lot of
Versatility to the keyboard itself as it
can be set up to your own personal
preference in my own case I've actually
been using both Wireless modes with two
separate computers switching between
each one using the switch found at the
back whilst this isn't the most elegant
way of switching modes it does work
pretty effectively and if you run a
multiple machine setup like I do then
this is pretty useful especially for a
keyboard in this price range in fact
this is a common theme when it comes to
the V10 Max the amount of functionality
it provides given its affordability at
the time of recording this keyboard goes
for just over $100 which in today's
landscape is actually pretty affordable
especially when it comes to Modern
keyboard pricing sitting below some of
the more popular gaming Brands out there
whilst offering a lot of similar
features one such feature is the five
macro Keys found on the left hand side
of the keyboard which ended up being
rather useful when it came to my own
workflow for example when making videos
I have a number of keyboard combos set
up so that I can easily perform certain
quick actions such as toggling a screen
recording or centering a window whilst
this works really well the combos can be
pretty complex
which ends up both being difficult to
remember and requiring much more
flexibility than my fingers often have
so to make things easier for myself I've
bound these keyboard shortcuts to
buttons on a stream deck but this also
comes with a couple of issues the first
of which is that it can only be plugged
into one device at a time which means in
my multimachine setup I have to have two
on my desk the second issue is the fact
that using the stream deck takes my
hands away from the keyboard whilst this
isn't a huge issue it is something I TR
try to minimize as much as possible both
of these issues can be solved by
programming the macro keys of the V10
Max in my case I've set the M3 macro to
the following key combination which when
activated will Center the current window
on the screen this works on both of my
machines as I have the same key
combination defined whilst it is a small
change it's the little things like this
that really help to improve my workflow
in fact this is an area where the V10
Max really shines especially for a
keyboard in this price range the of
customization the V10 Max runs qmk under
the hood which means you can pretty much
customize it however you want it also
comes with via support enabled as well
which means you can modify your keyboard
layout without needing to reflash the
firmware anytime you make a change
whilst you can still choose to modify
your keyboard layout using qmk on the
terminal this does have a learning curve
associated with it fortunately because
the V10 uses qmk with via this means you
can easily use a webbase configurator
such as the one that keycon provid sides
this is actually what I ended up using
to set up my own layout mainly because
of the Simplicity but also because it
supports all of the necessary features I
need for my own workflow optimized
layout for starters I've remapped the
caps lock key to be the modt behavior of
control and Escape which I've actually
done a whole video on as well as this
I've also made some modification to both
the left and right spacebar Keys the
left Space Bar Key has a layer tap
Behavior which means it acts as the
space key when tapped and and changes
the keyboard to my symbol layer when
held as for the right spacebar key I
actually remapped this to be the return
key instead one interesting thing about
this keyboard is that it provides a
function key that is next to the left
space bar one that's able to easily be
reached by your left thumb I actually
really like this key placement and it
makes the V10 Max feel very similar to
the Zsa Voyager although on the Voyager
I have this bound to something a little
bit more useful than the function key so
when it came to the V10 Max I wanted to
replicate this same key behavior however
in order to do so I needed to First find
a home for the function key especially
as I still used it to display the
battery level and toggle between
different Bluetooth hosts so in my case
I've moved it over to where the M5 macro
key is as for rebinding the actual
function key in my case I've set this so
when I tap it it acts as a backspace and
when I hold it it acts as left command
AKA left super if you happen to be on
Linux this becomes pretty much the same
functionality I have on my Zsa Voyager
but only costing a third of the price
whilst this feature is fantastic it's a
bit of a shame that the keyboard doesn't
have a similar key on the right hand
side as well if it had then I could
easily see myself using this full time
and I'd see this as a pretty compelling
affordable option especially when
compared to the more expensive split
keyboards one thing to note is that the
V10 Max also has a physical layout
switch at the back which by default
allows you to toggle between Mac OS and
windows layouts personally I I didn't
find much use for this but you can
actually modify these layers in the
configurator which means you could
modify this to something more custom
such as a layout for coding and one for
gaming if you desire I've talked a lot
about the affordability of this keyboard
and one thing to really be aware of is
the build quality in this case it's
absolutely fantastic out of all of the
keyboards that I've used recently this
one is definitely in the top three when
it comes to build quality when I compare
it to the glove 80 Which is far more
expensive the difference feels night and
day and that's not to say the glove 80
isn't well built it definitely is it's
just the keyron is incredible the key
caps and switches themselves feel very
premium and are a joy to type on not
only that but Kyron have also added in
Silicon sound dampening to this keyboard
which is something you probably won't
notice but actually is a good thing for
example if we take one of my other
favorite keyboards the Zsa Voyager if I
tap a key with some considerable Force
you can hear that there's a resonant
frequency Left Behind whilst it's not a
huge deal this is something I actually
find kind of annoying and so the fact
that Kyron have even taken this into
consideration is something I really
appreciate whilst we're on this subject
the keyboard comes with the Kyron kpro
switches in my case I have the banana
version which is described as a tactile
switch with a gentle noise profile
whilst using this keyboard I actually
found these switches to be rather
enjoyable to type on but if I had
decided that I wanted to swap these out
I could have easily done so as the
switches on the V10 Max are hot
swappable in fact Kyron provide their
own tool inside of the box that you can
use to switch these out overall the
Kyron V10 Max is a pretty great keyboard
especially given how little it costs if
you're in the market for a customizable
keyboard and can't afford the eye
watering prices of some of the next gen
ones then I would suggest giving the V10
Max a consideration as it has an awful
log going for it with that being said
the moonlander is still my favorite
keyboard at the moment but who knows
maybe there's something else out there
that will eventually Dethrone it
